newsitem.title: USA: Du Pont jury enters sixth day of deliberations.
newsitem.headline: Du Pont jury enters sixth day of deliberations.

text.p: After a day's rest, jurors in the John du Pont murder trial began their sixth day of deliberations on Monday, searching for consensus on a verdict.

The jury, which is confronted with eight possible verdicts in the case, was approaching their task with a new batch of visual aids they requested shortly before quitting on Saturday and taking Sunday off.
The six men and six women on the jury were given note pads, markers, easel board and tape to help them in their deliberations.
Du Pont, a millionaire chemicals heir, is charged with first and third-degree murder as well as voluntary manslaughter in the Jan. 26, 1996 killing of Olympic champion wrestler David Schultz.
Du Pont's lawyers have conceded du Pont killed Schultz, but are seeking a verdict of not guilty by reason of insanity.
In addition to verdicts of not guilty or not guilty by reason of insanity, the jurors can render verdicts of guilty or guilty but mentally ill.
On Saturday, Court of Common Pleas Judge Patricia Jenkins told jurors she could see they were having trouble reaching a verdict and hoped they were not confused by the legal issues in the case.
"Clearly you have had this case for many hours over several days. You are having, or are apparently having, some difficulty resolving some of the issues in the case," Jenkins said.
She said the difficulty was positive in that it reflected seriousness on the part of the jury.
